author: GoldenPresidio
body:
Never thought Meg Whitman was the right CEO for the job. She sucked at eBay: made shitty M&A deals, let Amazon run all over the company, and needed John Donahue to come in to clean up the culture to turn it into a silicon valley type company.

Then she completely underachieved at HP and essentially forced a company split with consumer and enterprise, that didn unlock any value.

Then at HPE she was canned in 3 months after the split lol

I have no idea why they picked her considering she didn't have any entertainment experience, and no stubhub (part of eBay Inc) doesn't count.

Also didn't help to actually launch a platform that was meant for commuting...during covid when nobody could use it because they didn't commute.

author: CycleFB
body:
Stocks or fds?

If looking for some mid to long term stock: 10k mtch, 10k rpm, 10k pton, 10k scl, 5k hpq, 5k rkt

Match is going to keep gobbling up dating apps, which i believe will remain to grow as they're common for genZ and will likely break into more parts of the world.  I could see them doing like dating games or some shit like the batchelor since their new ceo is some tv exec ceo dude.

Rpm is a coating company.  That are very aggressive in buying out companies, high margins, and coatings companies really aren't going to go bust anytime soon bc they're used fucking everywhere.  And as ppl push to move away from plastics, coatings will be needed even more.

Pton bc why not

Scl because they're a large powder coating company.  Powder coatings continue to grow bc of regulations on other paints.  And i like coatings..  axlta is descent too

Hpq because they have some big ass printers in the works that'll give crazy throughput, customization, and kill screen printing imo

Rkt bc it's literally a rocket


I've excited almost all my positions in the companies above and am selling puts to get back in to some positions if they dip in the next few months.

If FDs, I've been playing nnox, rkt, hpq, and hpe

author: Investinwaffl3s
body:
Not me, About $150k in AMD Epyc servers since last year.

Was a godsend while trying to scale out VDI this year. Intel all fucing backordered, only the highest SKU's in stock

AMD shipping out next day overnight. Thanks again HPE, always saving my clients ass when they sit on a quote for months on end and all of a sudden need everything overnighted

author: FlamingRadish
body:
I'm pretty new to this and there's some minor reasoning behind my portfolio:

.HPE (58.31%)
.AC (34.73%)
.TMR (6.97%)

My reasoning: HPE is a pretty well known brand with previous share prices between $15-25. I personally like the brand and don't think they've bitten the dust just yet, so I hope they'll get back to the previous prices.

Air Canada is low simply because of COVID. I definitely don't think that their drop is permanent and that they'll be up and going again once we find vaccine.

As for TMR, I had money left over on WealthSimple and wanted to diversify some more.

You can downvote me if you want, but I would appreciate it if you told me where I'm fucking up.

author: WillyGeyser
body:
HPE makes the least sense of all. They're showing profitability even as reopening is murky. They spent the last 4 years trading in the teens, now they can't crack $10/share.  


But if there is a big bubble in the big dogs, and that bubble pops, it'll drag these names down even more.

author: Rich265
body: it's cheap, I bought some yesterday. Not much, mind you. I think HPE is probably better deal.

author: Liquicity
body:
CCXX has 80 million shares (out of 110 million total) that are institutionally owned (59 total institutions), with 2 institutions (T. Rowe Price & Wellington Associates) owning about 28% of the **entire** SPAC. That's why the share price has been suppressed, to allow them to create their longs.   


I think retail investors are miserably wrong about this company. Annual revenue and EBITDA growth of 8-9% and 13%, respectively, are nothing to scoff at.   


Churchill management team has also said they're not actually taking a cut until there's a minimum 25% ROI **after** the first year of trading as MultiPlan. So yeah they're not just here to pump it and run away. Their lock-up period is 18 months, and the PIPE lockup period is 6 months in the shortest instance I believe.   


Also if you look at the people they're bringing on board, one used to run enterprise payments for Citigroup, and the other is a former COO from HPE (HP Enterprise), with an additional 2 decades at Microsoft. They're planning on beefing up the payment processing and software aspect, which will increase their already ridiculous margins and increase LFCF.   


This company is undervalued by at least 50%. Just because Nikola & Shell mooned doesn't mean every SPAC will end up at $50 pre-merger, but people are going to regret passing on this when it's trading at $30 within a couple of years\* and is paying out dividends to shareholders.   


Disclosure: Long CCXX/MultiPlan (full DD coming soon!)  


^(\*Barring a market melt-down prior to 2023, when interest rate hikes are projected to kick in)

author: Test-NetConnection
body: Benchmarks don't mean a lot if dell, hp, hpe, and all the other manufacturers keep using Intel. Despite amd benchmarks beating Intel for the past 2 years, Intel is still in every server I have ever sold.

author: JPete4985
body: It’s all about market outlook. Look at those companies 12 month and 5 year targets and you will understand. In the meantime as a new investor I’d recommend picking up AIG, GE, CCL, AMC, BAC, XLE, XLF, HPE, NOK... these are all stocks that are almost guaranteed to double if not triple over the next 3-5 years. A great place to park some long term cash... especially GE as they restructure. Energy sectors and oil will double as well as demand rises as we break out of the pandemic. Same for airlines... I see Alaska Airlines as the best value play. If I were you I’d invest in all of these industries that are down 50-70% and wait to reap your rewards. Value investing is better than chasing momentum in my opinion. Buy low sell high, easy enough. There are a couple momentum stocks I’d buy right now as in ASAP! Apple, Verizon, TMobile, Skyworks, Bloom Energy, Qualcomm, WiFi (boingo), these companies are set to reap the rewards and huge cash flow into 5g. SPY is a great diversified etc to park some cash too. It’s the ultimate set it and forget it stock. I would definitely recommend you check out some great etfs as a new investor.
